Messages.Author: Simon Matern
Messages.Content: Hallo!  Du suchst aktuell nach einem Nebenjob, der sich sehr gut mit deinem Studium vereinbaren lässt? Zudem möchtest du deinen Kommiliton*innen bei ihrem Lernerfolg unterstützen und Lehrerfahrung sammeln? Dann haben wir genau das Richtige für Dich: Bewirb dich jetzt als Tutor*in an der Fakultät IV!  Als Tutor*in leitest Du Tutorien in einer Veranstaltung Deiner Wahl und hilfst deinen Kommiliton*innen dabei, Kenntnisse zu vertiefen und Fertigkeiten einzuüben. Gleichzeitig kannst Du Dein Wissen vertiefen. Du würdest dich gern bewerben, hast aber Bedenken, weil du noch keine Lehrerfahrung hast? Keine Sorge, Lehrerfahrung ist keine Voraussetzung. Du erhältst zu Beginn Deiner Tätigkeit eine Schulung und wirst von einem engagierten Team unterstützt, sodass Du bestens vorbereitet bist.  Du willst dich bewerben? Dann schick einfach ein kurzes Motivationsschreiben, Deinen Lebenslauf und eine aktuelle Immatrikulationsbescheinigung sowie Deine Notenübersicht an tutvw@eecs.tu-berlin.de.  Weitere Informationen und Hinweise findest Du hier. Melde dich bei Fragen gern jederzeit bei uns!  Viele Grüße Deine Fakultät IV

Messages.Author: Simon Matern
Messages.Content: Hello everyone, the exercise tomorrow (17.04) is cancelled. Unfortunately, I won't be available.  The slides are uploaded. The first exercise is mostly organizational and provides a voluntary homework. I recommend solving the first homework, so you can setup your python environment and get a minimal OpenCV application running. Next week I will go over the organizational stuff and continue regularly.  See you next week!  Best Simon

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: Hi there, I tried the Test Exam and do have problems to understand Question 28 regarding the RNNs. I did not find anything related in the slides. Did we even cover RNN in the lectures ? My approach has h1 = a * h0 + a * x1 = 9 * 0 + 9 * 7 =  63 h2 = a * h1 + a * x2 d h2 / d a = h1 + x2 = 63 + 5 = 68 I tried many different other way but never reached 131. Can someone help me ?

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: I got it with help now. d h1 / d a = h0 + x1 = 7 d h2 / d a = h1 + a * d h1 / da + x2 = 63 + 9 * 7 + 5 = 131

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: Hi, are they yet any information available about the exam ? What kind of question can we expect ? Do we have program during the exam or is it a paper exam ? Are there any topics excluded from the exam ? Are topics from the assignments part of the exam ? Are there any exams from last semester we can use to study ? What utilities, own notes and tools are allowed during the exam ? Thanks in advance!

Messages.Author: Feriel Saber Cherif
Messages.Content: +1 I would also like to know

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: here my note from todays exercise:  General Notes - Test Exam on ISIS - actual exam will be digital on ISIS in the unix pool (like the test exam) - genreal understand concepts no much detail - gradient calculation: simple functions, calculate derivative, computing chain rule - most questions multiple choice - usually 4 answers - wrong answers for one question give minus points but rounded to 0 per question as lower limit - tools:     - cheat sheet is **not** allowed     - calculators are allowed     - paper for notes is allowed  Exam Topics  1. General CV - objection detection, classification - understanding concept of feature engineering and feature extraction - introduction slides - correspond to 6. Various  2. Hough / General Hough Transform / R-Tables - binary image - gradient information - tempalte - voting space    - difference between working with binary image and gradient information    - votings are different!    - gradient information returns one specific line and not various possibilities - how it works for line detection - improved versions of R-Tables    - correlations    - gradients and complex nubmbers - see homework - e.g. how could hough transform looks like for a circle - understand how to create an algorithmen   3. Baysian Methods - MLE/MAP/Bayes Estimation    - definitely one task where to estimate some parameter of some probability distribution (MLE ?)    - see homework - Discriminators / Classifiers    - giving a classifier: what is the error ?   4. Machine Learning in General - Bias-Variance Decomposition    - compute bias (or both) for certain estimator - Generalization (Train-Test Split / K-Fold)    - implification of bias and variance    - why use k-fold cross validation ?    - why dont we use the training data to evaluate the perfomance - underfitting and overfitting   5. Deep Learning (more signification Topic! 30-40%) - Architectures    - MLP: Parameters like depth, width (number of neurons)    - CNN: stride, kernel size, dilation, padding (signification part!)    - Transformers: Attention Methods, how do they work mathematically, why do we use the models - Optimization: SGD, Mpmemtum, Adam    - dont fully need to understand Adam    - typical question:       - graph (level set, function) given       - some kind of optimization goes through       - what is the most likely optimization function used here ?       - is there a small or large learning rate ? - Regularization: Batch-Normalization, Dropout, Residuals, Skip    - why we use them ? - Various Models (how we train the models)    - Autoencoder       - concept of embeddings (project data into much smaller space), trained feature space    - VAE    - GAN    - self supervised training (not too much into depth)    - supervised training (not too much into depth)   6. Various    - Saliency    - Implicit Shape Models

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: Hi, I have trouble to understand how and when to apply the binary mask in the first Assignment. If I understand Slide 46 correctly, implies to apply the binary mask on the gradient of the template. To clarify if I am understood correctly the notation from Slide 12 of Exercise 3: O(x,y) is the Object, I(x,y) is the original image and O^I is the objects gradient and I^I the images gradient. The function header calcBinaryMask declare the input as an image and should calculate the gradient it self. BUT step 2) of the slide 46 and the TODO in the correlation function needs compute the templates gradients and normalize it AFTER copying and circular shifting the templates gradient into a larger frame. Now my question: Should calcBinaryMaskimg normalize the templates gradient too ? Should the larger frame with the normalize and masked template gradient again be normalized ? Otherwise when calculation T = O^B * O^I I have a mismatch of size because O^B is large as the original template and O^I is in the larger frame in size of the original image I would be happy if someone can help me def calcBinaryMaskimg(img, thresh = 0.3):     """     Compute the gradient of an image and compute a binary mask     based on the threshold. Corresponds to O^B in the slides.     Parameters     ----------     img : ndarray         an image     thresh : float         A threshold value. The default is 0.3.     Returns     -------     binary : ndarray         A binary image.     """

Messages.Author: Moufid Tarek Zaamoum
Messages.Content: Hey, I'll try to answer your questions and help as I can :  1. Should calcBinaryMaskimg normalize the templates gradient too ? I think It doesn't matter, since the output is Binary, initially normalized or not the result is the same  2. Should the larger frame with the normalize and masked template gradient again be normalized ? I am not sure If I understand properly, but yeah the template you use for the correlation should be normalized. following the order of the tasks in the exercise, you should first have it in a larger frame ->apply circular shift -> normalize  3. for the mismatch T = O^B * O^I I think you tried to apply the mask to the "template gradient in large frame", I suggest you to first apply the mask to the original-frame template gradient then do the rest.  I hope this could help you Regards

Messages.Author: Moufid Tarek Zaamoum
Messages.Content: Let me add a correction: for the function calcBinaryMask, you should Not normalize otherwise the mask will be full of ones I was thinking about something else, I apologise.

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: Hi, on page 2 of the sheet for exercise 1 the goal is state as a black and white image by an colored image input. The description for the function binarizeImage states:     Given a coloured image and a threshold binarizes the image.     Values below thresh are set to 0. All other values are set to 255 The information for one pixel contains of three values (BGR). When I apply the threshold to each color value of each pixel, the image is of course not black and white, but with pixel which only 0 or 255 for each BGR values. Is this the supposed way or should  we set all BGR of one pixel to 0 / 255 according to the threshold ? If yes how to check for "Values" ?      B < tresh (AND, OR, XOR, ..) G < tresh (AND, OR, XOR, ..) R < tresh  Thanks!

Messages.Author: Marius Gehlhaus
Messages.Content: Hi Jonathan,  maybe convert the colored image to grayscale first and then apply thresholding. (e.g. see: cv2.cvtColor function on how to convert an image to grayscale)

Messages.Author: Thea Pagel
Messages.Content: The description of the provided functions and todos do not specify that it should be convert to grayscale. My solution is binarized isn't it ? Because my image only has values of 0 or 255.

Messages.Author: Ferdinand Benedict Laurin Brüninghaus
Messages.Content: https://opencv24-python-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/py_tutorials/py_imgproc/py_thresholding/py_thresholding.html First argument is the source image, which should be a grayscale image.
